08:30 Friday:@steve_maharey in a conversation about on the global challenges for higher education chaired by @Brian_MacCraithSteve Maharey is a former New Zeland Minister of Education and former Vice Chancellor of Massey University
A little more background about Steve here...
Welcome Steve
Thank you for coming to speak to us @steve_maharey
Dear Steve, A virtual welcome to Dublin!Thank you for participating in DCU Fuse!
Can I start with an easy question?!What in your view are the major challenges facing universities globally?

Hello Steve and good to have you with us as part of DCU-Fuse. Ireland is a small nation like New Zealand and I’m wondering drawing on your experience what role you think universities need to play in shaping the future of the Country?

I think our role is more important than ever. In my view universities do need to see themselves as engines of innovation/change. The times we live in are being driven by significant changes that we are all aware of - and the situation is made more complex by the rise of populism, antagonism to "experts" and an atmosphere of anger. We need to play a positive role in moving things forward.
Picking up on your last post and reflecting recent geo-political developments, how can universities best respond to the emergence of populism, fake news, anti-intellectualism etc.?
driven by significant changes
Given these changes what advice Steve can you give DCU about what we should include and consider in a new strategic plan?
what are the major changes that you would recommend?
We should avoid becoming politicians
This is a great observation! Very relevant to today's age.
Perhaps by contributing to the (re)-definition of literacy, and more importantly, literacies?
We must inform the politicians not become one of them
In the real world, we also need to engage with politicians
You're getting a lot of likes for that answer!!
Can you elaborate on what you see as some of the changes required to teaching and learning?
Universities do need to change substantially to be effective.

@steve_maharey  Your observation counters the Silicon Valley Narrative  that "education is broken" and only private Big Ed Tech can save us. Could you expand on this? What are the core enduring strengths that we can draw on?
Steve, this is a very important point!Academics rarely get listened to by politicians.How can we change that?
This will mean universities staff learning to operate in very different ways so they will be listened to by politicians.
David Perkins agrees and talks about moving from training memories to educating minds

I’ll be chairing this discussion and I’d like to thank Dr Ruth Freeman, Director of Strategy and Communications with SFI for joining us this evening at DCUFuse.
So to kick off the conversation, could I ask contributors to comment on external perceptions of DCU’s research strengths?

Good evening! My name is Blánaid White and I'm a lecturer in the school of chemical sciences here in DCU. I'll be helping to coordinate this evening's session. Looking forward to hearing your contributions!
Welcome Ruth!Thank you for participating.

The researchers at DCU are looking for solutions to real problems that are facing society and industry.
Hi Ruth, great to have you with us. Is there any particular area that immediately makes you think of DCU?
Ruth,One of the key challenges facing us is deciding on research priorities for the next 5 years.Can you comment on this from the SFI perspective (in terms of SFI priorities)?

Hi Ana - Hard to say - since you are putting me on the spot (!)I immediately think of synthesis and formulation of therapeutics, and neurotherapeutics. I think of medical devices and diagnostics.  Data analytics and communications.  Science Communication too.
I know there is a strong element of more 'fundamental' curiosity-led research at DCU too, but I would hazard a guess that externally DCU is seen more towards the 'applied' end? Thoughts?

I totally agree.  We have done an analysis of SFI's total portfolio.  About 80% of our funding goes to research in Technology Readiness Levels 1 and 2.  That's not too surprising given we have only had a remit to fund applied research for the last few years.  Many of our research centres are doing work across wide spectrum of TRLs.... and they are the frontier across those levels.

Thanks Ruth -didn't meant to put you on the spot! Just  genuinely wondered if internal perception of our strengths match those of our external stakeholders. Many of the areas that you mention are SFI funded, so I imagined your answer would be along those lines. We also have a lot of strong performers in other areas under SFI remit but perhaps we are not so well know outside because perhaps we lack critical mass in a particular area.

The digitization of higher education and how this requires a rethink of roughly everything that we do.

One approach that is in the early stages involves collaboratives/networks of higher education institutions exploring the digitization process. This new project is here and might be of interest to DCU: http://interlab.me/university-networks/

But this is just it, isn't it? What complexity and chaos tells us is that we may not be able to predict the consequences of our actions and decisions until these consequences emerge. Or at least, this is my limited understanding .

So we need to look at modules, programmes, schools, faculties as open dynamic (and at times chaotic) systems. And we need to embrace unpredictability and emergence in our curriculum (this does not mean that there is no plan...) and organisational structures rather than seeking to reduce the complexity.
(And of course, everyone else should feel free to chime in as we go!)

Engaged Students: a student engaged with society, communities and the world of enterprise is better equipped to deal with the challenges of working and living in a complex inter-dependent world.
Welcome all! Ronnie Munck, Head of Civic Engagement at DCU here.
I would like to first ask any local political representatives and Partnership colleagues out there to kick off.
Thanks for inviting me on.
Fair point.  I think that Dublin City Council and DCU could perhaps do more together?

One suggestion from a local resident to me, was to have an "Educational Festival" for the area around the three DCU campuses. The city council are interested in this idea. Would it be something that DCU would be interested in?
DCU in the community is such a great space, are there plans to develop community events, workshops or any other courses?

I'm not sure, though, about the concept 'city' as being distinctive of DCU. (I have always advised UK visitors not to refer to the University as 'city', which they are inclined to do, as people - e.g. taxi drivers - won't know what they mean.)  TCD, UCD and DIT would have at least an equal claim to 'city'.  We might perhaps look instead to our catchment areas in terms of geographical relevance?

Just flagging October 1st  is UN Day of Older People - for the past two years we have been doing a walk in Albert College Park - the strapline for the event is Say No to Ageism.  We usually do it with Third Age but this year there will be three organisations taking part - Age and Opportunity, Third Age and Active Retirement Ireland.  400 older people took part last year but younger people were thin on  the ground.  This is a great opportunity to engage with students and staff in DCU.  So brush off those walking shoes and get in shape for October 1st!

Student activism is almost as old as universities themselves.  As early as the 13th century, students have created collective movements in Paris and Bologna to effect change.  In the 20th Century, student activism and engagement with politics on issues such as the Vietnam war, the civil rights movement in the United States, and the civil rights organisation Peoples Democracy in Northern Ireland to name but a few.

This conversation with broadcaster and former USI President, Joe Duffy will explore the ways in which students can engage with politics and society.  We welcome students in particular to contribute to this discussion on how students as individuals, and as a movement can effect change within societies.

My favourite week as a student at Queen's in the late nineties was canvassing for a yes vote in the Good Friday referendum.
I think the role that young people played in the marriage referendum in 2016 was evidence that students and young people can be motivated to effect change in society.

Yes, I do realise that it is an issue.  Just a few issues from a student perspective.  The rent at the Postgraduate Accommodation went up by 10.5% last year, and while Campus Residences may be within the letter of the law this has had a profound effect of student budgeting.  There is also the issue that we will have to renew our contracts, and may be hard pressed to find alternative accommodation.  The combined campuses of the various universities really need to do something about this, as at present foreign students pay a significant proportion of the fees at our universities.  Should accommodation continue to rise in price, Dublin could become an undesirable destination from this perspective.

This conversation will explore they ways in which DCU interacts with international higher education institutions and engaging with students from around the world.  We will consider the key issues that will drive the development of our International Strategy, and look at the ways in which we can manage our major international partnerships more effectively.

Our conversation will initially focus on what we consider the key issues driving our International Strategy. We will endeavor to identify which regions globally should be the focus of our attention and explore the reasons why.  Should offshore educational partnerships be exploited more widely? A further focus will be on how best to utilise our digital platforms to engage internationally. I am looking forward to receiving your comments, suggestions and insights.

We also wish to explore the ways in which DCU interacts with international higher education institutions and students from around the world and look for ways to manage our major international partnerships more effectively.
We would especially like to hear the insights of our 3,000 strong international student body.

Is that Higher or Ordinary level Irish?

B2 is a level on the European Common Framework for Languages. It corresponds to a higher intermediate level of language, meaning that you have a broad understanding of a language. The higher levels, C1 and C2, means you can have complex conversations in a language.
There is some wonderful Irish language research going on in DCU. How is this being promoted outside DCU to people who do not speak Irish?

Cumann Gaelach is your best bet. They run classes, meetups and other social events throughout the year. They welcome all levels of Irish. Over the years, we have some international students join the society and learn Irish!

Cé go bhfuil an-chuid spéise agam sa teanga bheartaigh mé an trí rud a dhéanamh. Rinne mé na cuid de na hábhair oideachais trí Ghaeilge agus mé sa chéad bhliain agus sílim gur chuidigh seo go mór leis an taithí dearfach a bhí agam san ollscoil a chruthú. Sílim go raibh sé níos éasca orm cairde nua a dhéanamh mar bhí rud amháin ar aon intinn agam le gach duine eile sa rang cheana féin - go raibh muid uilig paiseanta faoin nGaeilge. Ar an drochuair, ní raibh na hacmhainní ann ag an am leanúint ar aghaidh leis na hábhair oideachais a dhéanamh sa dara, tríú nó sa cheathrú bhliain. Cé go bhfuil an-chuid acmhainní ar fáil trí Ghaeilge  san Ollscoil ó thaobh deiseanna acadúla agus go bhfuil dul chun cinn déanta thar na blianta, creidim fós go bhféadfadh muid níos mó a dhéanamh chun na hábhair oideachais eile a mhúineadh trí Ghaeilge ní hamháin sa chéad bhliain ach le linn na ceithre bliana. Is rud é seo nach bhfuil ar fáil i Marino, Froebel nó Mary Immaculate go bhfios dom agus sílim gur rud iontach é go bhféadfadh OCBÁC a fhorbairt.

Many students seem to treat subjects and modules as discrete entities and don't always see the skills that they develop (or could develop) while constructing discipline specific knowledge. So for me, the question is not what new modules we should have, but how can we integrate these generic skills, when should we teach them, where and how. For example, in the national project on digital literacies for language learning and teaching, it came very clear at the very beginning of the project that you could not separate digital literacies from language and from culture. But by working on the three together, learners can transfer their new skills to other languages and other domains.

I am not advocating a move to a general entry model either, but if we are likely to be forced to change to such a model, I think we should be  discussing options planning for it and thinking about how we preserve the DCU identity in such a scenario.

Most lecturers don't do that, so the big assignments come in the second half of the term, and it's an absolute killer. It's instant time-crunch across all of the subjects simultaneously. The assignments are hard, they're often group projects that require co-ordination and cajoling, on top of the second-half-of-term lectures being harder material too, so night study gets longer, and we're still holding down full time day jobs and parenting families.

In contrast - the first 4 weeks of term are often pretty light (the first week is generally completely empty).  Letting us scope out our assignments and prepare for them from day 1 enables us to balance the workload across the term (and find something really interesting and challenging!).
